content.rendered:
What is a Director?

Directors are the creative leaders of a film. They have control over the vision and direction of the screenplay/script. Directors are heavily involved in picking the cast, set and costume designers, and other creative roles on the film.

Where does a Director work?

  • Film/TV sets
  • Theaters
  • Advertising companies

How much does a Director make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Director is $36,000.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Directors?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Film majors
  • Drama majors
  • Media studies majors
Search Director jobs on Handshake

Director skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Directors succeed in their work:

  • Excellent leadership skills
  • Creativity
  • Understanding of technologist aspects of film software and editing

What are some common questions about Directors?

Q: How do I become a Director for film?

A: Many film Directors studied cinematography or a related major in undergrad and then went on to gain experience in the field. By holding internships, jobs, and by working on side projects, one can start their journey into becoming a Director.
